sp.p: No, no, Bobby, in The Reclaim'd Rake, and The Constant Lovers, and Sir Charles Grandison, and Roderic Random, and—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; they live at Random, with Sir Charles Grandison.—Now d'ye know 'em?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you are a charming little Lawyer, (to Sophy) and might, perhaps, establish your proofs for precedents, if Sir Charles Grandison was on the Bench: yet I never heard of his being made Chief-Justice, tho' I never thought him fit for any thing else.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What the Devil's this?—What, did not you bring all those fine proofs from fashionable life?—And are you such a fool as not to understand what we call common-place?

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Common-place!

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Yes, we persons of elegant life use the figure Hyperbōle.—

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Hyperbōle! What's that?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why, that's as much as to say, a stretch.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: A stretch! What, then, you have been mocking me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Not in the least; I shall be the happiest man existing to, to— (aside) Egad, I must take care of my phrases!—I mean, that I shall be always, and upon all occasions, your most devoted, tres humblement serviteur.—Were there ever two such Bumpkins!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: What's he gone? Oh! Villain! Monster! I am forsaken! Oh! I am rejected!—All Cornwall will know it!

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Tin-Mines and all. But don't ye cry, Miss Pendragon—don't ye cry!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Oh! I am rejected!

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
I am glad on't, with all my heart! I'll challenge him yet, and they won't know in Cornwall exactly how it was.—They'll hear that a Lord fought about ye, and all
that sort of thing; and whether for ye or against ye, 'twill be much the same.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: But will you challenge him, really, Bobby?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Upon honor!—I admire the claw of the thing! Egad, Sophy, I'm glad he's forsaken thee! Now my character will be finish'd. A man can't shew his face in company, till he has stood shot, and fired his pistol in the air.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: In the air! If you don't fire it thro' him—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Oh, never fear! I'll do all that sort of thing. Come along! I'll go home directly, and practise at the hen-coop in the yard. I'll fire thro' one end, and you shall hold your calash against the other; and if I don't hit it, say I'm no marksman.

div2.stage: [Exit Pendragon, with Sophy under his arm.

div2.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I intreat your pardon for conducting you to my own lodgings;—but here, Madam, you will be safe, 'till you determine how to act.—What are your commands for me?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Beauchamp, I have no commands—I have no designs!—I have been very imprudent; I am still more unhappy.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Shall I acquaint Mr. Fitzherbert?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: It was to avoid him that I left Lady Bell.—I have reasons that make it impossible to see Mr. Fitzherbert now.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Is there no other friend?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: O yes, I have one friend!—Were he here, all my difficulties would vanish!—It may seem strange, Mr. Beauchamp, but I expect that you believe—Heavens! here's company! (looking at the wing) 'Tis Miss Belmour—the last woman on earth whom I would trust!—Where can I go?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Miss Belmour! Very odd!—But pray be not uneasy!—That room, Madam, if you will condescend—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! I expect your gravity to be amazingly discompos'd at so hardy a visit; but I took it very ill that you did not design to call upon me before your departure;
and so as I was passing your door, I stopp'd in mere frolic to enquire the cause.

sp.speaker: Beauch
sp.p: You do me infinite honour, Madam! I am thankful that I fail'd in my attention, since it has procur'd me so distinguish'd a favour.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, your most obedient!—You are going to leave England for a long while! You'll find us all in different situations, probably, on your return!—Your friend Lord Sparkle, for instance—I am inform'd that he is really to marry Lady Bell Bloomer; but I don't believe it—do you?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, Madam, for me—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Poh! poh! impossible! Such friends as you are I suppose keep nothing from one another.—We women can't exist without a confidante; and I dare say, you men are full as communicative. Not that it is any thing to me; but as I have a prodigious regard for Lady Bell—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Heaven and earth, how unlucky! Here's some man! I am the nicest creature breathing in my reputation: what will he think? I'll run into this room.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, you cannot enter there!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I must—Oh—oh! the door is held, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: My dear Madam, I am infinitely sorry for the accident; but suppose—suppose, I say, Ma'am, that a friend of mine has been in a duel, and conceal'd in that room.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ridiculous! I saw the corner of a hoop and a white sattin petticoat:—is that the dress of your duelling friends? I will go in.— (struggling) So! (flinging away spitefully) 'tis too late!
So! so! so! I beg your pardon. How could you be so indiscreet, Beauchamp? Tho' a young soldier, I thought you knew enough of Generalship to be prepar'd for a surprize.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, so he was; but not for two surprizes.—One has happened already, and a hasty retreat the consequence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Believe me, Belville—I am infinitely concerned

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh! I detest your impertinent concern! Keep it for the Lady in the other room.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A Lady in the other room too! Heydey! Beauchamp, who would have suspected—

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: 'Tis all a mistake! The Lady in the next room—But prithee go.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Only tell me if you have seen Fitzherbert. I have been seeking him this hour, on a business of the utmost consequence.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I have not; but about this time you'll find him at home.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enough! Miss Belmour, pray suffer no concern; depend on my honour.—Beauchamp (taking him aside), who is the Lady in the other room?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Had I meant you to have known, that room would have been unnecessary.

div2.stage: (Belville seems still inquisitive; Beauchamp draws him towards the wing).

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now do I die to know who it can be! Indeed, 'tis necessary for my own sake.—Whilst she has been hid, I have been exposed; and who knows what the creature may say? I'll try once more. She has my secret, and I'll have her's.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Belville!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Miss Manners!—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh, Belville, throw me not from you!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Astonishing!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh charming! The modest Julia, and the reserv'd Beauchamp! Ha! ha! ha!—But Mr. Belville, how came you of this sober party? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Speak to me!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Beauchamp, you know the purport of my visit.—I had heard that Miss Manners has been seen to visit you, and, not being willing to trust to such a report, was resolved, if possible, to discover the truth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Wretched woman!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Barbarous creature! Oh hear me, I conjure you!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Hear you!—No, madam;—and if my contempt, my hatred, my—oh!—You, Sir, I must speak to in another place;—yet perhaps you were not acquainted that—What would I say!—The word which I have pronounced
with rapture, choaks me. From this moment farewel!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: What can I think of all this?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Permit me, Madam, to ask i you have long known Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, too long.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, oh, too long!—Aye, young ladies should be cautious how they form acquaintance. For my part—But you look ill, child!— (taking her by the hand) Well, I have no hard heart; I can pity your weakness, Miss;—I won't upbraid you now.—My coach waits;—shall I conduct you home?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, to Lady Bell—to Lady Bell—I am very ill!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Adieu, Mr. Beauchamp! This has been an unlucky frolic!—'Tis amazing, you grave people can be so careless.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: An unlucky frolick, indeed! And I am so thoroughly confounded, that I know not what judgment to form of the adventure.—I always considered Miss Manners as a pattern of delicacy and virtue; nor dare I now, spite of circumstances, think otherwise.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: So, so, Signor Quixote! What so soon lost your prize! Aye, you see quarrelling for these virtuous women, is as unprofitable as the assault of the windmills.—Have you seen Lady Bell in my behalf?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Lady Bell, my Lord! Why, sure, 'tis impossible after your attempt on Miss Manners—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Psha! that is a stroke in my favour. Women like to receive the devoirs of those, whom others of their sex have found so dangerous. What did you discover of Lady Bell's sentiment towards me?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I meant to have given the intelligence softened, but the agitations of my mind make it impracticable; I must, therefore, inform you in one word, Lady Bell Bloomer's choice is made, and that choice has not fallen upon your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
Then I must inform you in two words, that I
am convinced you are mistaken. But your reasons, Sir, your reasons?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Her Ladyship furnished me with a decisive one: she acknowledged a pre-engagement; and added, if I visited her this evening, I should see her in the presence of the man her heart prefers.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Excellent! charming ingenuity! Ha! ha! ha! the kindest, softest, message that ever woman fram'd; and you, like the sheep loaden with the golden fleece, bore it insensible of its value.—Ha! ha! ha! you can't see through the pretty artifice?

sp.speaker: Bauch.
sp.p: No, really.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Why, 'tis I who am to be there; there by particular invitation. You'll see her in my presence; and this was her pretty mysterious way of informing me that I am the object of her choice.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Without a doubt! But you deep people are the dullest fellows at a hint; a man of half your parts would have seen it.—But I am satisfied, and shall go to her route in brilliant spirits.—You shall come, and see my triumph confirmed.—Come, you rogue! and see the lovely Widow in the presence of the man her heart prefers.—Poor George! You must have been cursedly stupid, not to have conceiv'd that I was the person.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Yes, I will come.—Oh vanity! I had dared to explain—Yes, I construed the sweet confusion—Oh, I blush at my own arrogance! Lord Sparkle must be right.—Well, this night decides it.—Narrowly will I watch each tone and look, to discover—Oh!—ever-blest!—he whom her heart prefers!

div2.head: SCENE I.
div2.stage: An Apartment at LADY BELL's. A Table, with Candles.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: ARE the tables placed in the outer room?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am, all but the Pharaoh-table.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Then carry that there too.—I positively will not have a table in the drawing-room.— [Exit Servant. Those who play don't visit me, but the card-tables; and where they find them is very immaterial.—Let me see! For whist, Sir James Jennet—Lady Ponto—Mrs. Lurchem, and Lady Carmine.—For Pharaoh, Mrs. Evergreen, Lord Dangle, Sir Harry—Hey-dey!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Come, child, don't faint!—You had more cause for terror half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Heavens, Julia! where have you been?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ay, that's a circumstance you would not have known, but for an accident; and I am very sorry it fell to my lot to make the dicovery.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Speak, my love!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Miss Belmour will tell you all she knows.—I am too wretched!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, as to what I know,—I know very little.—I can tell what I saw, indeed.—Having received intimations not quite consonant to one's notions of decorum, I pretended a frolick, and called on Mr. Beauchamp, and there I found this Lady concealed.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Heavens, Julia! 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, she can't attempt to deny what I myself saw.—Other discoveries had liked to have been made too; but Miss Manners may explain them herself; for I see your rooms begin to fill.—I shall report that your Ladyship is a little indisposed, as an excuse for your not immediately appearing.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Julia! You at Mr. Beauchamp's!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Lady Bell, tho' I have acted rashly, and was indeed found there, I am not the guilty creature you imagine.—I am married!—I will no longer conceal it!

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Married! Oh Heavens!
sp.stage: (throws herself in a chair, with her back to Julia)

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I dared not reveal it to my guardian, and for that reason fled from your house.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: O Julia, and you are married! What a serpent have I nourished!—But forgive me!—You knew not—alas! I knew not myself, till this moment, how much—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My dearest Madam, do not add to my afflictions!—for indeed they are severe.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Ungenerous Girl! why did you conceal from me your situation?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Good Heavens! is it destin'd that one imprudent step is to lose me every blessing! In the agonies of my heart I flew to your friendship, and you kill me with reproaches.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: And you have killed me by your want of confidence! Oh, Julia! had you revealed to me—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I dared not; for when Mr. Belville prevailed on me to give him my hand—

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Mr. Belville!—Mr. Belville, say you?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes; it was in Paris we were married.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: So, so, so; what a pretty mistake I made!—But it was a mistake! . . . . . . . . . . And so my sweet Julia is married! married in Paris! Sly thing! But how came you at Mr. Beauchamp's, my Love?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: In my rash flight this morning, my wicked Maid betray'd me into Lord Sparkle's house.—There Mr. Beau—champ snatch'd me from ruin, and gave me a momentary asylum in his lodgings.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Did Beauchamp!—But what is his worth and his gallantry to me? Can't he do a right thing, but my heart must triumph?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: At Mr. Beauchamp's my husband found me;—and found me hid with so suspicious a secrecy!—Hah! Here comes Mr. Fitzherbert! How can I see him?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My Julia!—My dear Julia!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir!—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Come, I know all; and to relieve one cause of your distress, will tell you that the lover I shock'd you with today, was only my agent in the little revenge I had resolv'd to take for your having married, without my consent, the very man for whom all my cares design'd you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: —Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: At the moment he left Paris for Florence, you received my directions to return home: thus Belville's letters miss'd you, and he remain'd ignorant that you were in London.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir! had you reveal'd this to me this morning, what evils should I have escap'd?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: My dear girl, I decreed you a little punishment; but your own rashness has occasioned you a severer portion than you deserv'd.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: But where is the Bridegroom? I long to see the necromancer, whose spells can thaw the Vestal's heart, and light up flames in the cold region of a monastery.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: He is without, satisfied from the mouth of Beauchamp of your conduct, (to Julia) and impatient to fold his Julia to his heart.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Sir, lead me to him!—To find my husband, and to be forgiven by you, are felicities too great.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: What a discovery has Julia's marriage made to me of my own heart! I have persuaded myself it knew no passion but the desire of conquest; that it knew no motive to admiration but vanity; but the pangs of jealousy prov'd to me, in one moment, that all its sense is love!

div2.stage: An elegant Apartment lighted up, Card-parties seen.—Two Servants carrying Refreshments.—A Lady enters from the Top of the Stage, and comes down in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I protest I have been three quarters of an hour getting from the top of the street to the door!—I really believe, when people give routes, they think more of the bustle they occasion without doors, than the company they have within.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Oh yes! I am quite of that opinion.—The noise and racket in the streets are frequently the pleasantest part of the entertainment; and to plague one's sober neighbours is delightful! Ha! ha! ha! My next-door friend, Mrs. Saffron, always wheels into the country on my public
nights,—on pretence of her delicate nerves; but the truth is, her rooms will hold but six card-tables, and mine thirteen.

sp.speaker: 1st Gent.
sp.p: Well, I protest I wish the ladies would banish cards from their assemblies, and give us something in the style of the Conversaziones.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir Charles, that won't do on this side the Alps;—we have no knack at conversation:—we think too much to be able to talk. Good talkers never think. Sir Harry Glare, full of bons mots, never thinks.—I myself am allowed to be tolerable, yet I never think.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, that I believe all your friends will allow.—Hey-dey! here comes Lord Sparkle's borough acquaintance—Mr. Pendragon.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.p: Bobs, Miss Belmour, how d'ye do? I didn't think to see you.—Mr. Fitzherbert brought me here, and I have been examining every face, to see if I knew any body; but fine ladies are so alike, that one must have long intimacy to know one's acquaintance!—Red cheeks, white necks, and smiling lips, croud every room.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hey-dey! a natural curiosity!—Pray, Sir, how long have you been in the world?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: How long! Just twenty years, last Lammas.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Poh, I don't enquire into your age! How long is it since you left your native woods?—Was you ever at a route before?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Aye, that I was, last week!—It beat this all to nothing.—'Twas at our neighbour's the Wine-Merchant's—at his country-house at Kentish-Town.

sp.speaker: 2d Lady.
sp.p: Oh, lud! I wish I had been of your party! I should have enjoy'd a Kentish-Town route.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Oh, you must have been pleased; for the rooms were so little, and the company so large, that every thing was done with one consent. We were pack'd so close, that if one party moved, all the rest were obliged to obey the motion.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Delightful!—Well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
We had all the fat widows, notable misses, and managing wives of the parish; so there was no scandal, for they were all there.—At length the assembly broke up.—Such clattering, and squeedging down the gangway staircase,
whilst the little foot-boy hawl'd from the passage, "Miss Bobbin's bonnet is ready!"—"Mrs. Sugar-Plumb's lanthorn waits!"—"Mrs. Peppercorn's pattens stop the way!"

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, you creature, come with me! I must exhibit him in the next room.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, stay!—Take my card.—I shall have company next Wednesday, and I insist on yours.—He is really amusing!— (Enter Lord Sparkle from the top.) But hide your diminish'd heads, ye Beaus and Witlings! for here comes Lord Sparkle.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: I hope the Belles won't hide theirs; for in an age where the head is so large a part of the Lady, one should look about for the sex.

sp.speaker: 1st Gent.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, you see I have obey'd your summons! I should not have been here, notwithstanding Lady Bell's invitation, had you not press'd it.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: Nor I! I promis'd to meet a certain Lady in the Gallery at the Opera to night,—and I regret that I did not; for I see her husband is here.—Why did you press us so earnestly to come?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Why, 'faith, to have as many witnesses as I could to my glory!—This night is given by Lady Bell to ME.—I am the hero of the fête, and expect your gratulations. Here the dear creature comes!

div2.stage: LADY BELL comes down from the top, addressing the Company.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: How do you do?—how do you do? (on each side) You wicked creature, why did you disappoint me last night! Lady Harriet, I have not seen you this age! Oh, Lord Sparkle! I have been detain'd from my company by Mr. Fitzherbert, planning a scheme for your amusement.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Indeed! I did not expect that attention from him; tho' I acknowledge my obligations to your Ladyship's politeness.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: That air of self-possession, I fancy, would be incommoded, if you guess'd at the entertainment.—Have you seen Mr. Beauchamp?

sp.speaker: Spark,
sp.p: For a moment.—But, charming Lady Bell, (taking her hand) I shall make you expire with laughing. I really believe the poor fellow explained your message in his own favour, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Ridiculous! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis true! There they are, retired from the croud, and enjoying the privacy of lovers.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: See there he is! I long to have a little badinage on the subject.—Let us teaze him.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Oh, nothing can be more delightful!—"Hither, sighing shepherd, come!"—Come, Beauchamp, take one last, one lingering look!—sha'n't he, Lady Bell?

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Doubtless,—if he has your Lordship's leave.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: He seems astonish'd—ha, ha, ha!—Nay, it is cruel!—If the poor youth has the misfortune to be stricken, you know he can't resist fate.—Ixion sighed for Juno.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Yes, and he was punish'd too. What punishment, Mr. Beauchamp, shall we decree for you?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I am astonish'd!—Was it for this your Ladyship commanded me to attend you?

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: How did I command you? Do you remember the words?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: I do, Madam.—You bid me come this evening, that I might behold you in the presence of the man your heart prefers.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and now—now you see me!—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Oh, the sweet confusion of the sweet confession!

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! this ostentation of felicity, Madam, is ungenerous, since you know my heart; 'tis unworthy you! But I thank you for it—I have a pang the less.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, are you going?

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: This instant, Madam.—I came in obedience to your commands; but my chaise is at your door, and before your gay assembly breaks up, I shall be far from London, and in a day or two from England. I probably now see your Ladyship for the last time.—Adieu!

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Beauchamp!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Ay, prithee stay! I believe Lady Bell has a mind to make you her conjugal father at the wedding.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p:
I forgive you, my Lord.—Excess of happiness frequently overflows into insolence, and it is the privilege of felicity to be unfeeling.—But how, Madam, has the humble passion which has so long consumed my life, rendered me so hateful to you, as to prompt you to this barbarity? I have not insulted you with my love; I have
scarcely dared whisper it to myself: how then have I deserved—

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: O mercy, don't be so grave! I am not insensible to your merit, nor have I beheld your passion with disdain.—But what can I do? Lord Sparkle has so much fashion, so much elegance—so much—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: My dearest Lady Bell, you justify my ideas of your discernment: and thus I thank you for the distinguished honour

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Oh you false-hearted man!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Hey-dey!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Don't believe a word he says, for all you are so fine a Lady. He'll tell you of happiness and misery, and this, and that, and the other, but'tis all common-place and hyperbōlé—and all that sort of thing.

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Indeed! What has this young Lady claims on your Lordship?

sp.speaker: L. Bell.
sp.p: Claims! Ha! ha! ha! Surely your Ladyship can answer that in a single glance. Claims! Ha! ha! ha! Is it my fault that a little rustic does not know the language of the day? Compliments are the ready coin of conversation, and 'tis every one's business to understand their value.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: True, my Lord, true;—and pray instruct me what was the value of the compliment, when you told me I should make a figure in the Guards, and that you would speak to your great friends to make me a colonel?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Value! Why, of just as much as it would bring! You thought it so valuable then, that you got me a hundred extra votes on the strength of it; and you are now a little ungrateful wretch, to pretend 'twas worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: But here, Lord Sparkle, is a Lady who claims a right on a different foundation. She had no Election interest to provoke your flatteries, yet you have not scrupled to profess love to her, whilst under the roof of her friend, whose hand you was soliciting in marriage.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, I intreat your Ladyship not to fancy that you are to break the hearts of half our sex by binding Lord Sparkle in the adamantine chains of marriage.—I boast an equal right with you, and don't flatter yourself I shall resign him.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Mere malice, Lady Bell! Fitzherbert's malice!—I never had a serious thought of Miss Manners in my life.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: What, my Lord! and have you dared talk of love to that Lady without a serious thought?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Hey-dey! what right have you—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Oh, very trifling! only the right of a Husband—The Lady so honour'd by your love-making in jest is my wife; in course, all obligations to her devolve on me.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Your wife! My dear Belville, I give you joy with all my soul! You see 'tis always dangerous to keep secrets from your friends. But is any body else coming? Have I any new crimes to be accus'd of? Any more witnesses coming to the bar?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: No; but I am a witness in a new cause, and accuse you of loading the mind of my friend Beauchamp with a sense of obligation you had neither spirit or justice to confer.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell
sp.p: A Commission, my Lord, which was sent Mr. Beauchamp under a blank cover, by one who could not bear to see his noble spirit dependent on your caprices.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And when his sentiments pointed out your Lordship as his benefactor, you accepted the honour, and have laid heavy taxes on his gratitude.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Well, and what is there in all that? Beauchamp did not know to whom he was obliged; and wou'dn't it have been a most unchristian thing to let a good action run about the world belonging to nobody?—I found it a stray orphan, and so father'd it.—But you, Fitzherbert, I see are the lawful owner of the brat; so prithee take it back, and thank me for the honour of my patronage.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Your affected pleasantry, Lord Sparkle, may shield you from resentment, but it will not from contempt. Your effrontery—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
Effrontery! Prithee make distinctions!—What in certain lines would be effrontery, in me is only the ease of Fashion; that delightful thing, which enables me at this moment to stand serene amidst your meditated storm.—
Come, my dear Lady Bell, let us leave these good gentry, and love ourselves amidst the delights of fashion, and the charms of bon ton.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Pardon me, my Lord! As caprice is absolutely necessary to the character of a fine lady, you will not be surpris'd if I give an instance of it now; and, spite of your elegance, your fashion, and your wit, present my hand to this poor soldier—who boasts only worth, spirit, honour, and love.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Have a care, Madam!—Feelings like mine are not to be trifled with! Once already the hopes you have inspir'd—

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: The hour of trifling is past; and surely it cannot appear extraordinary, that I prefer the internal worth of an uncorrupted heart, to the outward polish of a mind too feeble to support itself against vice, in the seductive forms of fashionable dissipation.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Hey-dey! what, is your Ladyship in the plot?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: The plot has been deeper laid than you, my Lord, have been able to conceive. As I have the misfortune to be related to you, I thought it my duty to watch over your conduct. I have seen your plans, which generally tended to your confusion and disgrace; and many of them have been defeated, tho' you knew not by what means. But what fate does your Lordship design for these young people, decoy'd by you from their native ignorance and home?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Let them return to their native ignorance and home as fast as they can.

sp.speaker: Pend.
sp.p: No, no; hang me if I do that!—I know Life now, and Life I'll have—Hyde-Park, Plays, Operas, and all that sort of thing.—But, Old Gentleman, as you promis'd to do something for me, what think ye of a Commission?—The Captain there can't want his now; suppose you turn it over to me?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: No, young man, you shall be taken care of; but the requisites of a soldier are not those of pertness and assurance. Intrepid spirit, nice honour, generosity, and understanding, all unite to form him.—It is these which will make a British soldier once again the first character in Europe.—It is such soldiers who must make England once again invincible, and her glittering arms triumphant in every quarter of the globe.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p:
Well, Bobby may do as he will—I'll go back to Cornwall directly, and warn all my neighbours to take special
care how they trust to a Lord's promises at an Election again.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Well, great attempts and great failings mark the life of a man of spirit!—There is eclat even in my disappointment to-night; and I am ready for a fresh set of adventures to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Incorrigible man!—But I have done with you.—Beauchamp has answered all my hopes, and the discernment of this charming woman, in rewarding him, merits the happiness that awaits her; and that I may give the fullest sanction to her choice, I declare him heir to my estate. This, I know, is a stroke your Lordship did not expect.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: And was it then to you, Sir!—The tumults of my gratitude—

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Your conduct has compleatly rewarded me; and in adopting you—

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Oh, I protest against that!—Our union would then appear a prudent, sober business, and I should lose the credit of having done a mad thing for the sake of the man—my heart prefers.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: To you I resign him with pleasure: his fate is in your hands.

sp.speaker: Lady Bell.
sp.p: Then he shall continue a soldier—one of those whom Love and his Country detain to guard her dearest, last possessions.

sp.speaker: Beauch.
sp.p: Love and my Country! Yes, ye shall divide my heart!—Animated by such passions, our forefathers were invincible; and if we wou'd preserve the freedom and independence they obtain'd for us, we must imitate their virtues.
